unnormalised: IIT Delhi researchers have developed a new algorithm for solving linear equations faster! It seems complex, but at its core, it leverages something called 'sparse matrices'. Basically, instead of dealing with all those crazy numbers in a big grid, they focus on the important ones, the non-zero entries. They say this new method works especially well for problems involving massive datasets, like the ones used in AI and data science. Early tests show a speed boost of up to 30% compared to existing methods!
normalised: I-I-T Delhi researchers have developed a new algorithm for solving linear equations faster! It seems complex, but at its core, it leverages something called 'sparse matrices'. Basically, instead of dealing with all those crazy numbers in a big grid, they focus on the important ones, the non-zero entries. They say this new method works especially well for problems involving massive datasets, like the ones used in A-I and data science. Early tests show a speed boost of up to thirty percent compared to existing methods!

unnormalised: So, what does this mean for the average person? Well, faster calculations can lead to quicker and more efficient AI models. Think about things like improved weather forecasting, better medical diagnoses, or even more accurate financial predictions. All these things rely on solving complex linear equations.

unnormalised: The algorithm uses a technique that reduces the number of computations needed. Imagine you're solving a system of 1000 equations with 1000 unknowns. A traditional method may involve millions of operations. This new method, by cleverly exploiting the sparsity of the matrix (let’s say 99% of the entries are 0), it cuts down the calculations dramatically, maybe by 1/3rd! The code for the prototype is written in Python & MATLAB, and the team is looking into porting it to C++ for further optimization.
normalised: The algorithm uses a technique that reduces the number of computations needed. Imagine you're solving a system of one thousand equations with one thousand unknowns. A traditional method may involve millions of operations. This new method, by cleverly exploiting the sparsity of the matrix (let’s say ninety nine percent of the entries are zero), it cuts down the calculations dramatically, maybe by one third! The code for the prototype is written in Python and M-A-T-L-A-B, and the team is looking into porting it to C plus plus for further optimization.

unnormalised: The team, led by Prof. Mehra from the Mathematics Department, is currently seeking funding to further refine the algorithm and explore its applications in real-world scenarios. Prof. Mehra hopes this breakthrough will inspire more students to take up research in mathematics and contribute to solving some of the world's most pressing problems. They plan to publish a detailed paper in the Journal of Applied Maths later this year, around 12/2024.
